title: Corneal Edema: Symptoms, Causes, and Treatments
author: Paul Frysh

content: Corneal edema, also called corneal swelling, is a buildup of fluid in your cornea , the clear lens that helps focus light onto the back of your eye.

content_blocks.text: Corneal edema, also called corneal swelling, is a buildup of fluid in your cornea , the clear lens that helps focus light onto the back of your eye.

sections.heading: Causes of Corneal Edema
content: One common cause of corneal edema is a problem that affects the inner layer of your cornea. In most normal eyes, a membrane called endothelium pumps fluid out of the cornea. This keeps your vision clear and your eyes working as they should.
When the endothelium stops doing its job because of illness or injury, liquid builds up and your cornea swells. A number of conditions can cause this.

One of the most common is Fuch’s endothelial dystrophy. This happens when your genes cause the slow loss of the cells that make up the endothelium. It’s more common after age 50 and women get it more often than men.

Other possible causes of corneal edema include:
bullets: Some medications
Eye surgery
Contact lenses
Other medical conditions like herpes
Injury to your eye from a blow or a puncture
Inflammation due to problems like rheumatoid arthritis or specific eye issues like iritis or keratitis
Eye surgery
Poisonous substances that inflame, irritate, or damage parts of your eye

sections.heading: Symptoms of Corneal Edema
content: The first thing you might notice is blurry vision. Often, it might be the worst first thing in the morning and then get better throughout the day.
You might also have:
bullets: Eye pain or discomfort in light
Pain or tenderness when you touch your eye
A scratchy feeling in your eye
Hazy circles, or “halos,” around lights
In rare or serious cases, painful blisters in your eye

sections.heading: Diagnosis of Corneal Edema
content: Your doctor will talk with you about your medical history and any symptoms you might have. Then they'll examine your eyes. If your doctor thinks you might have corneal edema, they'll likely:
They might also measure the thickness of your cornea using a device called a pachymeter. Your doctor may use ultrasound to get a better look at your eye.
bullets: Look for scars or cloudiness on your cornea
Use magnifiers like a slit lamp or an ophthalmoscope to see details of your eye

sections.heading: Treatment of Corneal Edema
content: Which one you'll have depends on what causes your edema.
Some of the more common treatment plans include
bullets: Washing, or “irrigation,” of the eye with water or saline to get rid of toxic substances
Antibiotics for bacterial infections
Bandage contact lenses for damage to the surface of the cornea
Corticosteroid medications to ease swelling after injury
Medications for illnesses like inflammation or rheumatoid arthritis
Antiviral meds for viral infections
